div1.p: [Carter] details various methods of controlling malaria. He discusses segregation, screening, mosquito bars, and the use of quinine. [Carter] favors mosquito control because it does not require modification of human behavior.

div1.head: Report: Control of Malaria by Control of the Human Host, by [Henry Rose Carter], [1921]
div1.p:
Control of Malaria
by
Control of the Human Host.

As we agreed yesterday etc. if we can keep all infective men from
access to Anopheles the life-cycle of the malaria organism will be broken:
the organism will die and malaria disappear. and In proportion as we do
this, malaria will diminish--i. e. be controlled.

1/ One method is to move the men infective to Anopheles away from
the mosquitoes we wish to keep free from infection or what--from the stand-
point of Relativity--is the same thing, select the mosquitoes we would
keep free from infection at a distance from our infected men.

This is the “Segregation” on which so much importance is placed by
the British--and possibly too little by the rest of us:

House the men you would protect from mosquitoes so far from the
residences of infected men that A. feeding on the latter will not visit
the former. Simple, isn't it? Very rarely practicable in its entirety.

In its purpose it is comparable with screening; protecting the one
a class; the other a family--neither the whole community. Still, it is
well to protect individual families and classes--white Europeans the latter
are--when we can do no better. In neither case is this done to the de-
triment of the remainder of the countrymmunity. The principle then is a good one
and should be observed as much as is conveniently practicable.

2/ Screens and mosquito bars which prevent access of infected Ano-
pheles to uninfected men, also prevent access of uninfected Anopheles to
infected men and so act to prevent malaria by both methods. I think this latter ef-
fect of screening has been little noted and yet it is a very real one.
It was thus used intentionally to prevent the infection of mosquitoes at
Lonoke, Arkansas in 1918. The result aimed at--the protection of an avia-
tion camp from Anopheles infected in the village--was extremely good; but
other methods being also used, one cannot evaluate this factor in its pro-
duction.
production.

Segregation and screening, however, are of very minor importance in
the control of the human host. The methods depended on involve the use of
quinine.

There are 2 methods based on the use of quinine--both called the
“Method of Quinine Prophylaxis” yet absolutely distinct in method and dis-
tinct in immediate purpose. The one aims to so administer quinine to all
men infected with malaria that they will be freed from this infection and
thus be unable to infect Anopheles. The other--to so administer quinine to
uninfected men that they will not develope malaria even when bitten by in-
fected Anopheles. The one is primarily to prevent the infection of Ano-
pheles and thus of men: the other pays no attention to Anopheles, but aims
to immunize men against infection from them.

These methods then are not only different, but contrasting. One is,
and should be called, “Quinine Sterilization of Carriers:” the other “Qui-
nine Immunization.” Both are, indeed, Quinine Prophylaxis against Malaria,
but this term is definitive of purpose rather than of method and should be
discarded. There have been, and are, much confusion and many statements
at cross purpose in the Journals on account of not differentiating these
methods--calling them indiscriminately "uinine Prophylaxis.

3/ Method. Let us take up the method by quinine immunization
first. This is the Method of Celli: the Italian Method. Its object is
explained by its designation. Quinine is given daily--as Celli gave it--
or intermittently--as Koch and the Germans advise--to the uninfected men
of a community during the whole duration of the malaria season.

This method was used in Italy--by Celli--from 1902 to --at any rate--
1914. I presume it is still used: 40 gm., about 6 1/4 gr., per day was his
basic adult dose: 50 gm. in bad malarial districts. It was used on a large
scale and for a considerable time and the results -in Italy were distinctly good-.
Good results, but less good, were claimed by the Sergeants in Algeria
Algeria
3.
and in Greece by others. This method has been generally favored by the
Mediterranean people--less so by the French than the others.

The Germans in East Africa, for the same purpose, gave 1 gm. of
quinine on two successive days with an interval of from 6 to 8 days--
varying with the prevalence of malaria. There were various modifications
of dosage and of interval. Both the Germans and the Japanese, the latter
in Formosa, reported good, indeed excellent, results from this intermittent
dosage. This will be noticed later.

This method, quinine immunization, has never been favored, nor much
used by the British, who certainly have a very large field available for
both the exercise and the investigation of malaria control. It, quinine
immunization, is generally considered to have been entirely discredited by
its failure with the British troops in the Macedonian Campaign. This method
is by no means a favorite of my own, and yet I am not so sure that it fail-
ed as completely as asserted. Wenyon, who pronounces against it, gives
the general morbidity from malaria where quinine was used as somewhat un-
der 50% and that of the only unit to which he states no quinine was given
as 100% in 3 weeks' service. It may, then, have had more effect than it
was credited with. Castellani too, compares two units under, he thinks,
the same conditions, except that one took quinine and the other did not.
The first shewed a malaria rate of 45%, the other--in the same period--
one of 100%. Wenyon believes, as do Watson: Ian McDonald and Ozzard, that
it is far more efficacious in preventing malarial attacks than malarial
infections. This, too, is my own observation.
Balkans and Quinine.

4/ -- and last. Method: Quinine Sterilization of Carriers. This
is the so-called “Method of Koch”--the “Method of Stephansort.” It was
first used by Cosio at Grosseto in Northern Italy, at the instance of Koch,
in 1900: then by Koch himself at Stephansort, in German New Guinea-- the last
part of the same year and in 1901 by Frosch (assisted by Dr. Rivas, now of
now of
4
Philadelphia) at Brione--a small island in the Adriatic. Combined with
quinine immunization, by intermittent dosage, it was the method generally
used in German East Africa up to the time it ceased to be G. E. A.

Excellent results were reported at Stephansort and at Brione and,
except by Dempwolf, universally from German East Africa. Orenstein, how-
ever, who went to German East Africa after leaving the Canal Zone in 1914,
considered the result at Dar-es-Salaam--his station--a failure. The same
is asserted by Pearson, in charge there since the war, who has changed to
Control of Anopheles Production, I will add Pearson is an entomologist.
(Orenstein had a basis of comparison--a too perfect model--and Pearson
came after an interval during which the work had been stopped)

The work exclusively by the sterilization of the human host, prior
to 1916, was on a very small scale. Stephansort boasted of only 437 peo-
ple -157Carnius and Brione 131 people. That in German East Africa was combined with quinine
immunization. The only work on a comparatively large scale by this meth-
od is that done by Bass for the I. H. B. in this country in 1916-1920;

An area 10 miles square--100 sq. miles--was taken in a rural com-
munity in Bolivar County, Miss. and worked in 1916 and 1917. Good results
were reported by Bass--my recollection is over 70% reduction of malaria. I
do not think that he considered this work entirely satisfactory--part of it
being experimental. In 1918 then, basing his work on the experience ac-
quired the past two years--a similar area of 10 miles square--containing
10,000 souls--was taken in Sunflower County, Miss. For this year Bass re-
ported a reduction of 89%--at a cost of $1.16 per head, exclusive of super-
vision. This work was continued during 1919 and (probably imperfectly) in
1920. The Report of the Rockefeller Foundation gives the end reduction for
the 3 years at 55%.
I told you that the training of streams: the removal of water, was essentially an engineering problem

This is a as clearly a medical problem--the laboratory to determine which
are the carriers: the therapist to determine the method of freeing them
from infection and, again, the laboratory to determine when they are freed
freed
5.
from infection.

It may be noted here that this method has been favored only by phy-
sicians, and especially such as are bench-men: Koch and his followers:
Celli: Bass: James. On the contrary that it is damned by entomologists.
(“There is nothing like leather!” says the Cobler.)

Koch determined his carriers by a blood examination of all persons
in the Countymmunity--it was a small one. To all found positive--and only to
these--quinine was administered:--1 gm. daily until parasites disappeared
and thereafter the same dose was continued on two consecutive days with
an interval of 7-8 days for 2 to 2 1/2 months. The same method was used
in East Africa with some modifications, the interval being shortened to 6
or even 5 days in badly malarious districts and quinine being continued in
this way indefinitely to all, whether they had been Carriers or not: a combination of Koch's method with Q. immunization

Very obviously, when this sterilization of carriers at Stephansort-say- took place (even
supposing that all carriers were sterilized) infected Anopheles were in
flight and quinine sufficient to prevent re-infection--i. e. in immunizing
doses--had to be continued until the death or freedom from infection of
such Anopheles. This, I think, is the reason (although not so stated in
Koch's report) for the long continuance of quinine after the disappearance
of the parasites--and in smaller doses. He evidently regarded not finding
parasites as equivalent to freedom from infection--an opinion with which
few would now agree.

If that was the reason for the cont'nce of
the Aim. Why he gave no Q. to those whose blood he did not find &?
Immune to Inf. biolog. otherwise..

Bass, in 1918, administered 10 gr. of quinine per day--in a single
dose at bed-time--for two months. He gave this to all (1) whose blood was
found to be positive and (2) who gave a history of malaria the previous
siason. ObviouslyI presume, the long continuance of this treatment was sufficient
to protect--immunize--against the infected Anopheles in flight, when the
sterilization of carriers was completed. It continued until they were dead
or free from infection. I do not think, however, that it was continued
continued
6.
with that intention--simply to cure the infection. Bass knew well enough
that mere failure to find parasites (on a single examination did not neces-
sarily negative infection--and relapse. Hence his long continued dosage

Very obviously, it would be quite an advantage, in any case, to avoid
this chance of reinfection--i. e. sterilize our carriers when infected Ano-
pheles were not in flight. This, generally speaking, is impracticable in
the Tropics--where Koch tried this method. On my return from Panama--where
the same conditions held--I thought that we might avoid this trouble in
the U. S. and have better results if our quinine sterilization could be
done during the season when Anopheles, at any rate infected Anopheles,
were not in flight--i. e. in the early spring--Jan. to March.

The question at once arose--did the parasite hibernate in the mos-
quito--which, as of course you know, does hibernate. If so, freeing our
men of infection would do little good as they would be later reinfected
by these hibernated parasites. There was no data on the subject for the
U. S. Such as we had--Maritano's findings in the Maremna--implied that
the parasites did so hibernate.

An examination was made by Mitzmain (Mayne) of a large number of
hibernated Anopheles imagoes, at Scott, Miss. in 1914 and later at Talla-
dega Springs, Ala. and at Monroe, La.--1,211 at Scott. I do not recall
the number at the other two places. None of these imagos, taken up to lat-
ter April or early May were infected with plasmodia. These results were
corrobotated--incidentally--by the observations of King on mosquitoes from
Mound. La.

From this it is an allowable deduction that in the U. S., except
maybe in the extreme South, the plasmodium does not hibernate in its in-
sect host. Man is clearly--in this section--the only winter carrier of
malaria.

It seems advisable then to take advantage of this finding and begin
our Quinine sterilization in --say--March or April.
April.
Discussion and Comparison of Methods.

1/ Under both of the Principal Methods of Malaria Control some de-
tail methods are individualistic and some are community measures--e. g.
the use of screening and of hand-catching in Control of the Insect Host
are primarily individualistic measures and as such comparable with segre-
gation: screening and quinine immunization--also individualistic--in the
Control of the Human Host.

On the other hand--Control of Anopheles Production and Steriliza-
tion of Carriers are both distinctively community measures and to be ef-
fective, must be carried out on a community scale.
Advantages of Community measures over Individualistic.
Resort to latter when 1st. fail. -Canipare

Of the general methods I have given you, which is the best? It de-
pends on the conditions--local and temporal--at this place, at this time.
You do not ask what is the best stimulant or the best analgesic? It de-
pends on the conditions for its us. We have considered the general ad-
vantages of community measures over individualones and, as a further guide,
I would say that method is the best which gives sufficient malaria control
at the least cost or which gives greatest (and sufficient) control at the
same cost. This is “the Law and the Prophets!” It is a question of ecomon-
ics: each problem to be decided on its own merits-there and then existing.

Where economically practicable, however, the Control of Anopheles
Production is, to my mind, clearly the Method of election, and yet I am a
physician with, at least an appreciation of laboratory values, and not an
Entomologist. But I have seen both tried.
My reasons:
1/ Work done once for all. Afterward the

2/ Upkeep is usually comparatively small and decreasing from year
to year.

3/ Experience has shewn that this kind of work has always been
been
8.
kept up--i. e. is permanent.

4/ Work is with material, water: clay: sand: stone not people--and every Health Officer etc.
will tell you that no material etc. is so refractory as people can be.

5/ Both installation and upkeep are directly carried out by the
H. O.--or Malaria Engineer--and in no wise dependent on the cooperation of
the individuals--of all the individuals--in the community.

6/ The locality stays free from malaria independent of the movement
of population.
7/ Getting rid of Anopheles--usually of all mosquitoes--as a pest.

On this Method--Control of Anopheles Production--the great bulk--
practically all of our Malaria work now going on in the U. S. is based.

The objections to this method--Control of Anopheles Production--
are (1) the cost and (2) the time necessary to get results. The first has
always to be considered: The last sometimes makes it advisable to choose--
temporarily at least--a quicker, if less permanent method. I will give you
an instance later.

The results of Quinine Sterilization of Carriers are, I fear, little
apt to be permanent in the U. S. Their permanence depends on the permanence
of a population in a locality and our people move about too much. At Ste-
phansort and Brione this was not so.

Not only is there a more or less constant passing of people from the
territory in which Anopheles are infected into our territory, where they
are not infected--our people returning from visits and strangers visiting
us--but in the rural districts of the South--for which this method has been
especially recommended--there is at the end of the cotton year--a whole-
sale movement of tenant-farmers. This, I suspect was the cause of the re-
duction of the result in Sunflower Co. from 89% in /18 to 55% in 1920, al-
though work was continued. The results in places handled by Control of
Anopheles Production have improved year by year. Roanoke Rapids, for in-
stance, begun in 1914, gave a reduction of 99% in 1916--the last data I have.
I have.

The fundamental objection to both of the Quinine Methods of Con-
trol is their non-permanence. Quinine Immunization, from its very nature,
must go on from year to year--in perpetuity, so to speak. If its total
annual cost--in trouble: inconvenience and money is greater than the upkeep and the in-
terest on and upkeepthe first cost of, Control of Anopheles production and an equal Con-
trol of Malaria is given, it is permanently economically good. If its to-
tal cost be greater than this interest and up-keep it is permanently econo-
mically bad. The chances for the permanence of the results of Sterilization
of Carriers is better than the above and in places this will, I believe, give be
permanent. results. But in the parts of the U. S. where Malaria Control is
most needed--they are not good.
Yet there are conditions where Quinine Control is to be chosen.
Mitchell County, Ga.

Good that year, and so good, that we were practically compelled to con-
tinue them the next 2 years--while the County was taking the permanent meas-
ures--Screening Houses and Draining--of Mosquito Control
Continued good results--many white people--working their own lands.

There are other cases too, in which Quinine Control by lessening the
malaria in a community, enabled it to do more permanent work of Anopheles Control--
which they had never attempted until this incubus was lifted: Sunflower, Co.
etc. Unless it thus leads to Mosquito Control it will, I fear, be of no
great permanent benefit to the more malarious districts in the U. S.
Results--Read from Reprint.
Combination of Methods--James.
My own idea--Wilson and Ruleville.

Malcolm Watson--the most ardent, and probably the ablest British ad-
vocate of Control of Anopheles Production--uses Quinine to enable men to live
in the country until they can control Anopheles Production.
